did.abstract: An anthropologist, Pamela Wallace was the Head of Education at the Sam Noble Oklahoma Museum of Natural History at the University of Oklahoma. The papers include correspondence, research, works by Wallace, tapes recording, color slides, photographs and video of Yuchi Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Pamela Wallace Papers include the full range of professional correspondence, research, works by Wallace, and a sizeable portion consisting of tapes recording Yuchi language classes, genealogical interviews, and tribal matters.

Native American Images note : Over 3,000 images of the social and ceremonial dances of the Yuchi people, consisting of 350 color slides, 1,300 color and black and white photographs with 1,400 color negatives. Taken from 1994-2000 by Pamela Wallace, the photographs reflect Yuchi men and women performing the arbor, ribbon, buffalo, and lizard dances at the annual Green Corn Festival. Performed at the Polecat and Duck Creek ceremonial grounds of Oklahoma, Native Americans are shown in costume, particularly the women’s shake tortoise and milk-can leg rattles. Also includes a video of the arbor dance and topographical maps with plotted Yuchi sites as part of an Oklahoma archeological survey. Long absorbed into the Muskogee (Creek) Nation, the Yuchi’s distinctive customs and traditions remain this tribe’s unique cultural identity.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: An anthropologist by training, Pamela Wallace was the Head of Education at the Sam Noble Oklahoma Museum of Natural History at the University of Oklahoma. Pamela Wallace earned a master’s and PhD in Anthropology at the University of Oklahoma. Wallace began her professional interest while completing her master’s in anthropology, focusing on the Euchee (Yuchi) language and culture. She became involved with the tribe’s struggle for federal recognition while completing her master’s degree, and continued assisting tribal efforts through her doctorate. Wallace specialized in building a demographic and linguistic history of the Yuchi people, and aided in many language classes sponsored by the tribe. A recognized authority on the Yuchi people, Wallace also was an assistant editor of Ethnohistory. Active in the professional community, Wallace was a member of American Society for Ethnohistory and on the board of directors of the Oklahoma Anthropological Society.
